occurrences.line_text: His course of Iustice he was forst to stay,
Or stay till he his armes, which were thereby,
It to performe: so after little stay,
And in his tender armes her forced vp to stay.
Where was his won; ne did the other stay,
To make there lenger stay, forth on his iourney goth.
Ere long he ouertooke, and forst to stay,
Would not permit, to make their lenger stay,
That seemed nought the course thereof could stay:
Stay stay, Sir Knight, for loue of God abstaine,
Stay stay, Sir Knight, for loue of God abstaine,
Procur'd the Prince his cruell hand to stay,
But after he had fed, yet did he stay,
To stay their cruell hands from slaughter fell.
Tho to him running fast, he did not stay
Where all the rest for him did readie stay,
She stayd, and foorth Duessa gan proceede,
Whom hardly he from flying forward stayd,
From Turkes and Sarazins, which them had stayd;
He stayd his steed for humble misers sake,
He stayd not for more bidding, but away
But Trompart stoutly stayd to taken heed,
Approching nigh, he neuer stayd to greete,
Yet there the steele stayd not, but inly bate
Eftsoones his cruell hand Sir Guyon stayd,
Him stayd from yielding pitifull redresse;
They stayd a while: and forth she gan proceed:
Backe to the strond retyrd, and there still stayd,
And of him catching hold him strongly stayd
But Guyon lightly to him leaping, stayd
Him backward ouerthrew, and downe him stayd
And all the while his wounds were dressing, by him stayd.
Yet stayd they not, but forward did proceed,
They stayd not to auise, who first should bee,
The mortall steele stayd not, till it was seene
For nothing would she lenger there be stayd,
But yet the end is not. There Merlin stayd,
Ne lenger stayd for th'other to reply,
The martiall Mayd stayd not him to lament,
His wearisome pursuit perforce he stayd,
The wicked steele stayd not, till it did light
She made those Damzels search, which being stayd,
But when he stayd, to flight againe she did her take.
All, that I euer found so wisely stayd;
So forth they far'd, but he behind them stayd,
Ne stayd he, till he came vnto the place,
Ne stayd his flight, nor fearefull agony,
Therewith she stayd her hand, loth stayd to bee;
Therewith she stayd her hand, loth stayd to bee;
But like to warie Centonels well stayd,
But he her quickly stayd, and forst to wend withall.
And by no meane could in the weight be stayd.
The other stayd behind to gard the pray.
Her wrathful hand from greedy vengeance to haue stayd.
Yet stayd she not for them, but forward fared,
She stayd not to aduise which way to take;
Stayd not, till she came to her selfe againe,
Tho when she had his execution stayd,
Ne once for ought her speedy passage stayd,
They stayd their hands, when she thus gan to speake;
Stayd not, till through his curat it did glyde,
So both for rest there hauing stayd not long,
That in short space, whiles there with her he stayd,
Ne stayd to aske if it were he by name,
With that his mortall hand a while he stayd,
To cheare his guests, whom he had stayd that night,
With speare in th'one hand, stayd him selfe vpright,
Wherefore he stayd, till that he nearer drew,
A stranger wight in place, her plaint she stayd,
And greedily him griping, his auengement stayd.
They stayd not there, but streight way in did pas.
Ne stayd, till that he came into the hall:
He stayd his second strooke, and did his hand abase.
Approching to him neare, his hand he stayd,
The villaine stayd not aunswer to inuent,
Like many water streames, a while she stayd;
So being stayd, they her from thence directed
Whose course is often stayd, yet neuer is astray.
The matrone stayd no lenger to enquire,
That th'outrage of his violence he stayd,
He stayde his hand, and gan himselfe aduise
And left to losse: his stalking steps are stayde
For it the goodly peace of stayed mindes
Held on his course with stayed stedfastnesse,
He stayed not, but in his armes her bearing
Ne stayed further newes thereof to learne,
Ne stayed step, till that he came at last
Where long he stayed not, when as a Knight
He stayed not t'aduize, which way were best
With stayed steps, and graue beseeming grace:
There she awhile him stayes, him selfe to rest,
Ne stayes, till safe himselfe he see from ieopardy.
Ne stayeth leaue to take, before his friends doe dye.
Who staying nought to question from aloofe,
As when her face is staynd with magicke arts constraint.
That her gay garments staynd with filthy gore,
And staynd their prayses with thy least good part;
And all their armours staynd with bloudie gore,
Whose waters with his filthy bloud it stayned:
Had stayned with reprochfull crueltie,
Into whose stead faire falshood steps,
In stead thereof he kist her wearie feet,
In stead of rest, she does lament, and weepe
In stead of foe to wound my friend amis?
His cruell sport, in stead of sorrow dew;
Vnto that stead, their strife to vnderstond;
Fly therefore, fly this fearefull stead anon,
Mote stead you much your purpose to subdew.
Two goodly Beacons, set in watches stead,
Then afterwards he in his stead did rayne;
In stead of fraying, they them selues did feare,
For he ne wonneth in one certaine stead,
In stead thereof sad sighes, and sorrowes deepe
And therewith crowne himselfe in th'others stead:
In stead thereof sad sorrow, and disdaine
In stead of rest thou lendest rayling teares,
In stead of sleepe thou sendest troublous feares,
And in her litle loues stead, which was strayd,
In stead of eyes two burning lampes she set
In stead of yellow lockes she did deuise,
As Florimells faire haire: and in the stead
And in his stead let Loue for euer dwell,
In stead thereof know, that your louing Make,
As that in stead of praying them surcease,
In stead thereof sweet peace and quiet age
Himselfe he wisht haue beene, then in so bad a stead.
She in my stead supplide his bestiall desire.
From loftie steede, and mounting in their stead
Him chaunst; in stead of his ï¿½mylia faire
As if in stead thereof they Chaos would restore.
In seate of iudgement, in th'Almighties stead,
In stead of right me seemes great wrong dost shew,
In stead whereof she made him to be dight
In stead of Curiets and bases fit for fight.
But that in stead therof, she sternely bade
In stead of whom finding there ready prest
But rather let in stead thereof to fall
And doe in stead thereof mild curt'sie showe
Next that ye Ladies ayde in euery stead and stound.
In stead of comfort, which we should embrace:
Had not this wylde man in that wofull stead
Yet would not let her lite, nor rest a little stead.
In stead of steelehead speare, a shepheards hooke;
And did it put on Coridons in stead:
He ran at him enrag[e]d in stead of being frayde.
And round about in fittest steades did place,
The knight gan fairely couch his steadie speare,
Whose steadie hand was faine his steede to guyde,
Whose staggering steps thy steady hand doth lead,
And slombring soft my hart did steale away,
To steale a snatch of amorous conceipt,
So did she steale his heedelesse hart away,
Her loue-sicke hart to other thoughts did steale;
To steale away, that I with blowes haue wonne,
To weet how he her loue away did steale,
And steale from thee the meede of thy due merit,
That able was weake harts away to steale.
And steale away the crowne of their good name;
Did secretly out of her prison steale;
And time to steale, the threasure of mans day;
Then did he cast to steale her thence away,
That from her self vnwares he might her steale the whyle.
Whose steale was yron studded, but not long,
To search out those, that vsd to rob and steale,
And gracious speach, did steale mens hearts away.
And both the eyes did steale the hart away.
Crept in by stouping low, or stealing of the kaies.
That ere one be aware, by secret stealth
Restraining stealth, and strong extortion;
Darke was the Euening, fit for louers stealth,
She sought to saue, as thing reseru'd from stealth;
Of stealth and spoile, and making nightly rode
His charet swift in haste he thither steard,
Whiles th'one did row, and th'other stifly steare;
For whom he turnd him selfe into a Steare,
But senselesse stood, like to a mazed steare,
As doth a Steare, in heat of sommers day,
By strength haue ouerthrowne a stubborne steare,
Sterne was their looke, like wild amazed steares,
Vpon his foe, a Dragon horrible and stearne.
Which fled so fast from that same foster stearne,
And manhood rare, but terrible and stearne
He stearnly shooke, and therewith fierce did stryke
And false Duessa in her sted had borne,
His gorgeous ryder from her loftie sted
The souldier may not moue from watchfull sted,
Great God it planted in that blessed sted
And pitteous Elidure put in his sted;
Was by the people chosen in their sted,
Now comes to point of that same perilous sted,
And now they nigh approched to the sted,
What shape, what shield, what armes, what steed, what sted,
To search each secret of that goodly sted,
Ensewd, whose noyance fild the fearefull sted,
In sted thereof with drops of melting loue,
And beath'd in fire for steele to be in sted.
He staggered to and fro in doubtfull sted.
And to them does the steddy helme apply,
With th'other staide his Lady vp with steddy might.
But the stout Prince, with much more steddy stowre
His seuenfold teme behind the stedfast starre,
As rocke of Diamond stedfast euermore.
And stedfast truth acquite him out of all.
The stedfast globe of earth, as it for feare did quake.
Her stedfast eyes were bent, ne swarued other way.
And seemd vneath to shake the stedfast ground.
To moue the world from off his stedfast henge,
Transformd her to a stone from stedfast virgins state.
Whose right haunch earst my stedfast arrow strake?
His stedfast life, and all his actions frame,
That to a stedfast starre his course hath bent,
Ne backward shrinke, but as a stedfast towre,
Their stedfast stonds did mightily maintaine,
With stedfast hand vpon his horse did stay,
Lookt on them louely, still in stedfast state,
With stedfast courage and stout hardiment;
In stedfast chastitie and vertue rare,
In so great prayse of stedfast chastity,
But now in stedfast loue and happy state
Her former loue, and stedfast loialty,
Ne her out of the stedfast sadle driued,
Though much emmou'd, but stedfast still perseuered.
Yet thousand charmes could not her stedfast heart remoue.
But still with stedfast eye and courage stout
For stedfast still her eyes did fixed rest,
Alwayes, to execute her stedfast doome,
Ne loose that he hath bound with stedfast band.
Be well aduiz'd, that he stand stedfast still:
They tied were to stedfast chastity,
And wading through the waues with stedfast sway,
And loued simple truth and stedfast honesty.
But the steele-head no stedfast hold could fynd,
I plighted haue, and yet keepe stedfastly:
Him stedfastly he markt, and saw to bee
He would through temperance and stedfastnesse,
Held on his course with stayed stedfastnesse,
The Dwarfe him brought his steed: so both away do fly.
His fair enchaunted steed, and eke his charmed launce.
Dismounting lightly from his loftie steed,
But got his ready steed, and fast away gan ride.
And by his side his steed the grassy forage ate.
Whiles he had keeping of his grasing steed,
His stubborne steed with curbed canon bit,
From loftie steed, and downe to sleepe me layd;
Als flew his steed, as he his bands had brast,
Of his froth-fomy steed, whose courage stout
Who taught his trampling steed with equall steps to tread.
Vouchsafe to stay your steed for humble misers sake.
He stayd his steed for humble misers sake,
From his tall steed, he rusht into the thicke,
Gay steed with spurs did pricke, the good Sir Mortdant was.
He left his loftie steed with golden sell,
Sith his good steed is lately from him gone;
He left his steed without, and speare besyde,
He that braue steed there finding ready dight,
Purloynd both steed and speare, and ran away full light.
With noyse whereof he from his loftie steed
So to his steed he got, and gan to ride,
But he the rightfull owner of that steed,
His steed was bloudy red, and fomed ire,
His forlorne steed from him the victour wan;
But later ages pride, like corn-fed steed,
To decke his herce, and trap his tomb-blacke steed.
What herce or steed (said he) should he haue dight,
When vnder him he saw his Lybian steed to praunce.
And vnder neath him his courageous steed,
Tho comming to his Squire, that kept his steed,
To take him from his steed full tenderly,
And counsell sage in steed thereof to him applyde.
His fomy steed, whose fierie feete did burne
But to his starting steed, that swaru'd asyde,
And all her steed with tinsell trappings shone,
What shape, what shield, what armes, what steed, what sted,
Then gan he freshly pricke his fomy steed,
And from his loftie steed dismounting low,
And clombe vnto his steed. So forth he went,
His steed eke seem'd t'apply his steps to his intent.
That from his steed he fell in deadly swowne;
Her Steed did stagger with that puissaunt strooke;
On Tromparts steed her mounted without stay,
Tho hastily remounting to his steed,
His stolen steed to thunder furiously,
And his forwandred steed vnto him got:
With that he put his spurres vnto his steed,
Fiercely forth prickt his steed as in disdaine,
And as it fell, his steed he ready found.
It chaunst Sir Satyrane his steed at last,
Lightly Cambello leapt downe from his steed,
With woody mosse bedight, and all his steed
That for to winne the saddle, lost the steed.
Yet she no whit dismayd, her steed forsooke,
More hard for hungry steed t'abstaine from pleasant lare.
Bearing a litle Dwarfe before his steed,
In steed of whom forth came I Placidas,
And on his steed her set, to beare her out of sight.
His owne good steed, which he had stolne, to clame;
And gan inquire, how was that steed bereaued,
Lo there Sir Guyon, take to you the steed,
That his good steed, all were he much renound
Downe streight to ground fell his astonisht steed,
But Burbon streight dismounting from his steed,
He with strong hand down fro[m] his steed me throw'th,
Vpon his steed, for no iust cause accused,
Vpon the steed of her owne late dead knight:
To take him vp behinde vpon his steed:
But as thou hast thy steed forlorne with shame,
Nor his fierce steed, that mote him much dismay,
That from his steed him nigh he drew againe.
Bene helped through the swiftnesse of his steed,
It chaunst some furniture about her steed
Where seeing him so lie, he left his steed,
His angry steede did chide his foming bitt,
Then mounted he vpon his Steede againe,
For him so far had borne his light-foot steede,
He set her on her steede, and forward forth did beare.
And had his staggering steede not shrunke for feare,
From loftie steede, and bad the Ladie stay,
But vnder him a gray steede did he wield,
But his fierce foe his steede could stay vneath,
To turne his steede about, or sure he should be ded.
Vnto his lofty steede he clombe anone,
Sitting in shade beside his grazing steede;
Like to a stubborne steede whom strong hand would restraine.
Whose steadie hand was faine his steede to guyde,
From loftie steede, and mounting in their stead
But from my lofty steede dismounting low,
Either the other from his steede to cast;
And mounting to her steede, bad Talus guide her on.
But tooke her steede, and thereon mounting light,
And in their steede for other rayment sought,
When he was readie to his steede to mount
And low dismounting from his loftie steede,
Vpon his steede, whiles she no whit gainesayd,
And setting on his steede, her did sustaine
Turned his steede about another way,
Vpstaying still her selfe vppon her steede,
Withouten armes or steede to ride vpon,
His steede now strong through rest so long a space,
A trampling steede, that with his neighing fast
The whiles the saluage man did take his steede,
He left his lofty steede to aide him neare,
At night doth baite his steedes the Ocean waues emong.
And flaming mouthes of steedes vnwonted wilde
And coleblacke steedes yborne of hellish brood,
With dread whereof his chasing steedes aghast,
And his faint steedes watred in Ocean deepe,
Faire shields, gay steedes, bright armes be my delight:
Turne we our steedes, that both in equall tilt
Their firie Steedes with so vntamed forse
And drawne of cruell steedes, which he had fed
So long as in his steedes the flaming breath did last.
And eke his steedes like to an hungry hound,
Of his owne steedes was all to peeces torne,
After all which vp to their steedes they went,
Letting their steedes to graze vpon the Green:
And with his steedie staffe did point his way:
Their steeds do stagger, and amazed stand,
To menage steeds, as did this vaunter; but in vaine.
Sheilds, steeds, and armes, & all things for thee meet
They tooke their steeds, & forth vpo[n] their iourney went.
Tho to their ready Steeds they clombe full light,
Retyrd their steeds, to ronne in euen race:
There might ye see loose steeds at randon ronne,
They tooke their steeds, and forward thence did pas
As when the firie-mouthed steeds, which drew
Such was the furie of these head-strong steeds,
And with his mortal steel quite throgh the body strooke.
So hugely stroke, that it the steele did riue,
To taste th'vntryed dint of deadly steele;
The cruell steele so greedily doth bight
Washing his bloudy wounds, that through the steele were cleft.
That deadly dint of steele endanger may:
Not made of steele, nor of enduring bras,
Whose hartstrings with keene steele nigh hewen be,
With mortall steele him smot againe so sore,
Were wont to riue steele plates, and helmets hew,
Like plated coate of steele, so couched neare,
Both deadly sharpe, that sharpest steele exceeden farre.
But stings and sharpest steele did far exceed
The pointed steele arriuing rudely theare,
The percing steele there wrought a wound full wyde,
But backe againe the sparckling steele recoyld,
Whom fyrie steele now burnt, that earst him arm'd,
I wote not, whether the reuenging steele
Vpon the ioynt the lucky steele did light,
Whiles cursed steele against that badge I bent,
As gentle Hynd, whose sides with cruell steele
Out of her gored wound the cruell steele
With strokes of mortall steele without remorse,
And eke of surest steele, that may be found,
As steele can wound, or strength can ouerthroe.
The quiuering steele his aymed end well knew,
That the sharpe steele arriuing forcibly
Yet there the steele stayd not, but inly bate
The mortall steele despiteously entayld
That first did teach the cursed steele to bight
Of his great G[r]andmother with steele to wound,
Ne mortall steele emperce his miscreated mould.
The vertue is, that neither steele, nor stone
That vertuous steele he rudely snatcht away,
The faithfull steele such treason no'uld endure,
That through his thigh the mortall steele did gryde:
And cleauing the hard steele, did deepe inuade
In glistring steele, and strongly fortifide:
That euer brandished bright steele on hye:
That halfe the steele behind his back did rest;
The mortall steele stayd not, till it was seene
Her wrathfull steele, that none mote it abide;
The wicked steele through his left side did glaunce;
The cold earth was his couch, the hard steele his pillow.
The wicked steele stayd not, till it did light
Or that the wicked steele empoysned were:
Whose shadie boughes sharpe steele did neuer lop,
He was all armd in rugged steele vnfilde,
Sith dint of steele his carcas could not quell:
Yet nathemore the steele a sunder riued,
And the sharpe steele doth riue her hart in tway,
The cruell steele, which thrild her dying hart,
That nought mote stay the steele, till in his side
With point of steele, that close his hartbloud spild,
The wicked steele for mischiefe first ordained,
Whose raging rigour neither steele nor bras
Fell downe to ground, as if the steele had sence,
And beath'd in fire for steele to be in sted.
But the sad steele seizd not, where it was hight,
And on his head a steele cap he did weare
The tempred steele did not into his braynepan byte.
That the cold steele through piercing, did deuowre
And the mad steele about doth fiercely fly,
With his sharpe steele, and ran at him amaine
With that he stiffely shooke his steelehead dart:
Through all those foldes the steelehead passage wrought
But the steele-head no stedfast hold could fynd,
In stead of steelehead speare, a shepheards hooke;
Stuft with steele-headed darts, wherewith she queld
And fairly couching his steele-headed speare,
And eft auentring his steeleheaded launce,
Their steel-hed speares they strongly coucht, and met
The steely head stucke fast still in his flesh,
And stroke the Pagan with his steely brand
When so he list in wrath lift vp his steely brand.
Which steely brand, to make him dreaded more,
Out of her steely armes were flashing seene,
Whose long rest rusted the bright steely brand;
That from like inward fire that outward smoke had steemd.
When the last deadly smoke aloft did steeme,
The inward smoke, that did before but steeme,
Which ye may see yet all about me steeme.
Out of his stinking gorge forth steemed still,
Dame Venus girdle, by her steemed deare,
His life he steemed dearer then his frend.
And in her bloud yet steeming fresh embayd:
And cruell blades yet steeming with whot bloud,
And saluage with their bloud fresh steeming red,
Strong Allo tombling from Slewlogher steep,
Amid the bowels of the earth full steepe,
Doth euer wash, and Cynthia still doth steepe
That my fraile eyes these lines with teares do steepe,
Vnder the steepe foot of a mountaine hore;
And sighes, and grones, and euermore does steepe
And in my heart his yron arrow steepe,
Forth to an hill, that was both steepe and hy;
A litle path, that was both steepe and long,
Now gan the golden Phoebus for to steepe
In that knights heart, and wordes with bitter teares did steepe.
His flaming head did hasten for to steepe,
His wandring thought in deepe desire does steepe,
Then she with liquors strong his eyes did steepe,
Which ouer-hanging, they themselues did steepe,
Adowne so fast, and all his armour steepe,
Or that darke dreadfull hole of Tartare steepe,
Their fleecy flowres they tenderly did steepe,
Which did her lilly smock with staines of vermeil steepe.
That nought she did but wayle, and often steepe
The drunken lampe downe in the oyle did steepe,
The slouthfull bodie, that doth loue to steepe
The flesh therewith she suppled and did steepe,
Vnder a steepe hilles side it placed was,
Did sharpen them, and in fresh poyson steepe:
And with her teares his wounds did wash and steepe.
Ne cared she her wound in teares to steepe,
Through the thicke clouds, in which they steeped lay
With dreadfull force falles on some steeple hie;
That in the lake his loftie crest was steept,
Of nightly stelths and pillage seuerall,
In slouthfull sleepe his molten hart to steme,
That with the steme thereof the Temple swet,
They stemme ech other with so fell despight,
And like a girlond did in compasse stemme:
That all the ayre about with smoke and stench did fill.
That all the land with stench, and heauen with horror choke.
A direfull stench of smoke and sulphure mixt
And to the ground her threw: yet n'ould she stent
And euery lincke thereof a step of dignity.
Ne stayed step, till that he came at last
At euery step vppon the tiptoes hie,
From so high step to stoupe vnto so low.
His wanton stepdame loued him the more,
His cruell stepdame seeing what was donne,
Phrixus and Helle from their stepdames feares,
